text: The Cohors I Asturum et Callaecorum (civium Romanorum) (1st cohort of the Asturians and Callaecans) was a Roman auxilia unit. ==Description== The soldiers of the cohort were recruited from the Asturians and Callaecans in the territory of today's Asturias and Galicia. The soldiers of the Unit had been granted Roman citizenship at a certain time. However, this did not apply to soldiers who were taken into the unit after this time. They received the Roman citizenship only with their honorable discharge (Honesta missio) after 25 years of service.Margaret M. Roxan: The Auxilia of the Roman Army raised in the Iberian Peninsula Volume 1. discovery.ucl.ac.uk, 1973, p396-407 Since there are no inscriptions of milliaria (1000 men) and equitata, so it is to be assumed that it is a pure infantry cohort (Cohors peditata). The target strength of the unit was 480 men, consisting of 6 centuria with 80 men each. ==History== The first proof of unity in the province of Mauretania Tingitana is based on an inscription found in Volubilis, dated AD 57 (ILM 00058).Margaret M. Roxan: The Auxilia of the Roman Army raised in the Iberian Peninsula Volume 1. discovery.ucl.ac.uk, 1973, S. 396-407 Possibly, the cohort was around 60 temporarily in the province of Illyricum John Spaul: Cohors² The evidence for and a short history of the auxiliary infantry units of the Imperial Roman Army, British Archaeological Reports 2000, BAR International Series (Book 841), , p79-80 Volubilis socle.Locations of the cohort in Mauretania Tingitana were: *Ain Schkour: Several inscriptions indicate the presence (of parts) of the cohort in Ain Schkour. John Spaul assumes that the unit was stationed in Ain Shkour.John Spaul: Cohors The evidence for and a short history of the auxiliary infantry units of the Imperial Roman Army, British Archaeological Reports 2000, BAR International Series (Book 841), , p79-80 *Volubilis: Prefect Nammius Maternus' tombstone was found in VolubilisMargaret M. Roxan: The Auxilia of the Roman Army raised in the Iberian Peninsula Volume 2. discovery.ucl.ac.uk, 1973, p149-151(728-730),Jörg Scheuerbrandt: Exercitus. Aufgaben, Organisation und Befehlsstruktur römischer Armeen während der Kaiserzeit. Dissertation, Albert-Ludwigs-Universität Freiburg im Breisgau 2003/2004, p176 ==Known Commanders== Commanders included *Aemilius *Caius Vibius Salutaris (CIL 3, 6065) *FlaviusMargaret M. Roxan: The Auxilia of the Roman Army raised in the Iberian Peninsula Volume 2. discovery.ucl.ac.uk, 1973, p149-151(728-730), (oder C. Iul.)John Spaul: Cohors The evidence for and a short history of the auxiliary infantry units of the Imperial Roman Army, British Archaeological Reports 2000, BAR International Series (Book 841), , S. 79-80 Neon (CIL 8, 21820) *Gaius Iulius Longinus (AE 1955, 208) *Lucius Domitius Dentonianus (CIL 2, 4211) *Nammius Maternus (AE 1916, 91, CIL 16, 167) *Publius Valerius Priscus (CIL 6, 3654) ==See also== *Cohors II Asturum et Callaecorum ==References== Category:Auxiliary equitata units of ancient Rome
title: Cohors I Asturum et Callaecorum
